Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the 20 percent increase in young people coming back to Buffalo. The actual increase according to Census Bureau data is 29 percent, which is higher than the claimed 20 percent.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support as it does not provide specific data or sources to back up the 20 percent increase.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in the young population is solely due to young people coming back to Buffalo, whereas the expert suggests that some of the increase may be attributed to the aging of the millennial generation.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert suggests an alternative explanation for the increase in the young population, stating that it could be due to young adult migrants from the rest of the Buffalo-Cheektowaga-Niagara Falls metro area or gains from immigration from other countries.
Falters at times: The claim falters by using data for Erie County instead of specifically for Buffalo, which could lead to a misrepresentation of the actual increase in young people coming back to Buffalo.
Understate: The claim may be understating the increase in young people coming back to Buffalo, as the actual increase according to Census Bureau data is 29 percent, higher than the claimed 20 percent.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that it used data for Erie County instead of Buffalo itself, leading to a potential misrepresentation of the actual increase in young people.
